title: Ambiguity between parsing the same ident in a macro

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: A-macros
labels.description: Area: All kinds of macros (custom derive, macro_rules!, proc macros, ..)

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
I tried this code ([playground link][1]):

```rust
macro_rules! foo {
    (
        bar: [
            $(
                {
                    baz: [$($crab:ident),*],
                    cor: [$($turtle:ident),*]$(,)*
                    $(gar: [$(urchin:ident),*])*$(,)*
                }
            ),*
        ]
    ) => {};
}

fn main() {
    foo!(
        bar: [
            {
                baz: [pink, fluffy],
                cor: [],
            },
            {
                baz: [nyan, cat],
                cor: [cute, funny, friendo],
            }
        ]
    );
}
```

I expected for this to compile.

Instead, the compiler errors in a local ambiguity between what appears to be the same identifier:
```
error: local ambiguity: multiple parsing options: built-in NTs ident ('crab') or ident ('crab').
  --> src/main.rs:23:23
   |
23 |                 baz: [nyan, cat],
   |                       ^^^^
```

### Meta

Tested locally on a recent nightly and stable:

`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.51.0-nightly (b12290861 2021-01-29)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: b122908617436af187252572ed5db96850551380
commit-date: 2021-01-29
host: x86_64-pc-windows-msvc
release: 1.51.0-nightly
LLVM version: 11.0.1
```
```
rustc 1.49.0 (e1884a8e3 2020-12-29)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: e1884a8e3c3e813aada8254edfa120e85bf5ffca
commit-date: 2020-12-29
host: x86_64-pc-windows-msvc
release: 1.49.0
```

Also tested on the [playground][1] on latest nightly.

[1]: https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=6768107c3d5454c3322382f1cc670125
